comments:
This junior-level laboratory course covers applications related to biotransport, biomedical instrumentation and biological signal and system analysis.

Students had mixed reviews about the course structure and experiments. One liked the diversity of topics but suspected their real-world applications, while another student liked having finally “learned the implications of the signals and systems material in a real lab setting.” A number of students indicated they did not learn enough MATLAB to complete assigned problems, which turned out to be the most difficult and time-consuming portions of the lab report write-ups. A few pointed out the uneven distribution of workload among group members, in which some members would be burdened with MATLAB coding.

Students liked Professor Tsourkas’s two-week lab format, which allowed them to better prepare for the experiments during the second week. However, some indicated experiments often didn’t work, and it would be helpful if he stayed for the entire duration of the lab as problems usually arise later.

Students described Professor Rizk as “fantastic” and “available to questions and concerns.” Students pointed out his experiments often work well and illustrated the theoretical principles learned. There were mixed reviews about his hour lecture at the beginning of each lab period. Some felt it was helpful in reminding them the relevant concepts and goals of the experiments, while commented it was "not helpful" and "not many people were paying attention".

This six-hour laboratory course is required for junior BE majors, who are required to have completed BE209, BE210, and have completed or be taking concurrently BE324 and BE301 to take this course. A number of students commented on the 10+ hours of outside the classroom to finish the lab report, which some felt was unfair in addition to the 6-hour laboratory and the difficulty of scheduling a meeting time for group members. A student also commented that the Professor Tsourkas’s “check-list” grading does not take into account the quality of discussion in the lab write-ups.
